questions.text: Two days after hospital admission and surgical treatment for a cut on his right thigh from a sickle, a 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with wound swelling, fever, chills, and severe pain. He had a similar injury 4 months ago that resolved after treatment with bacitracin ointment and daily dressings. He works on a farm on the outskirts of the city. He appears anxious. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a 6-cm edematous deep, foul-smelling wound on the medial surface of the right thigh. The skin over the thigh appears darker than the skin on the lower leg. There are multiple blisters around the wound. Light palpation around the wound causes severe pain; crepitus is present. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis usually becomes pathogenic in immunocompromised patients, especially those with invasive devices like catheters, central lines, or surgical implants. This patient has no such device and is not immunocompromised, making the organism an unlikely cause of his symptoms. Moreover, S. epidermidis is not associated with the development of gas gangrene.

B) CORRECT:

Gas gangrene is a life-threatening necrotizing soft tissue infection most commonly caused by the rapid proliferation and spread of Clostridium perfringens from a contaminated wound. Clinical features include excruciating muscle pain, edema with subsequent skin discoloration (red-purple to black), and gas production. Crepitus is generally present, as well as a feathering pattern of gas on soft tissue imaging. To have a chance at survival, this patient should receive empiric antibiotic treatment and undergo surgical debridement immediately.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative aerobic bacterium that can cause skin and soft tissue infections in immunocompromised patients. The most common infections caused by P. aeruginosa are ecthyma gangrenosum, burn wound infections, osteomyelitis, and folliculitis associated with hot tub use. P. aeruginosa is an unlikely cause of necrotizing soft tissue infection, especially in a patient who is not immunocompromised.

D) INCORRECT:

Species of the Rhizopus and Mucor genera can cause mucormycosis, which may involve deep tissue necrosis manifesting with features similar to those seen in this patient. However, since this patient is neither immunocompromised nor diabetic, infection with pathogens from these genera is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is one of the most common causes of soft tissue infections, including cellulitis, skin abscesses, and folliculitis. However, it is not a monomicrobial cause of gas-containing necrotizing fasciitis and is only sometimes involved in polymicrobial cases. A different pathogen is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a common cause of infection in animal bite wounds, especially those from cats. Infection with the organism can result in cellulitis, abscess formation, and even necrotizing soft tissue infection, which would cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. This patient does not, however, have a history of animal bites, making this pathogen very unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus is a pathogenic bacterium found in marine environments. Although V. vulnificus can also cause necrotizing soft tissue infections, it is less likely than other causes, especially in a patient without a history of exposure to marine environments.
questions.hint: Severe pain, fever, crepitus, darkened skin, and blisters around a deep, foul-smelling wound suggest gas gangrene, a rare subtype of necrotizing fasciitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency room for severe left leg pain several hours after injuring himself on a gardening tool. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F) and his pulse is 105/min. Physical examination of the left leg shows a small laceration on the ankle surrounded by dusky skin and overlying bullae extending to the posterior thigh. There is a crackling sound when the skin is palpated. Surgical exploration shows necrosis of the gastrocnemius muscles and surrounding tissues. Tissue culture shows anaerobic gram-positive rods and a double zone of hemolysis on blood agar. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of cellular damage caused by the responsible pathogen?

choices.text: Degradation of cell membranes by phospholipase
Increase of intracellular cAMP by adenylate cyclase
Inactivation of 60s ribosome subunit by N-glycosidase
Inactivation of elongation factor by ribosyltransferase
Inhibition of neurotransmitter release by protease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endotoxin is a part of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) component of gram-negative bacterial cell walls and causes cytokine release (IL-1, IL-6) as well as complement and macrophage activation. Clostridium perfringens (present in this patient's tissue culture) is a gram-positive bacteria and lacks LPS. Moreover, LPS-induced complement activation would result in hypotension and/or septic shock rather than gas gangrene.

B) CORRECT:

The alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens is a lecithinase that degrades cell membrane phospholipids. Degeneration of membrane phospholipids leads to cell lysis and myonecrosis, resulting in gas gangrene, as seen with this patient's bullous lesions and crepitus. Additionally, the lecithinase activity of this toxin causes hemolysis, which characteristically manifests as a double zone of hemolysis on blood agar.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased activation of adenylate cyclase and intracellular cAMP is mediated by the heat-labile toxin of enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). This overstimulation results in increased secretion of Cl- and H2O in the GI tract, causing watery diarrhea. This gram-negative organism is not associated with cutaneous infections or development of gas gangrene.

Several other bacterial toxins mimic adenylate cyclase activity. These include the edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis and the cholera toxin of Vibrio cholera. The heat-stable toxin of ETEC increases guanylate cyclase activity by increasing cGMP.

D) INCORRECT:

Shiga toxin produced by Shigella species inactivates the 60S ribosomal subunit of rRNA, which inhibits protein synthesis and causes enterocyte necrosis. This gram-negative bacteria is not associated with cutaneous infections or gas gangrene.

E) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin A is an AB toxin produced by several bacteria (Pseudomonas aeruginosa) that works by inactivating eukaryotic elongation factor-2 via ribosylation. Penetrative lesions in the lower extremities are classically associated with pseudomonal infections (and are fostered by high-moisture environments such as running shoes). Clostridium perfringens (present in this patient's tissue culture) produces a toxin that works via a different mechanism.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani is a protease that cleaves SNARE proteins, which are required for neurotransmitter release. Clostridium tetani can also be contracted via traumatic body injury, often with old/rusty equipment. However, it does not cause gas gangrene or hemolysis, and classically presents with muscle spasms, lockjaw, and risus sardonicus.
questions.hint: This patient's myonecrosis is likely caused by alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for severe pain in her left thigh at the site of a stab wound that occurred earlier in the day. The wound has mild crepitus, a minimal foul-smelling exudate, and marked purplish discoloration.
A CT scan of the left thigh (figure) demonstrates massive muscle necrosis (figure arrows) coupled with extensive gas production (figure asterisks).
She is taken to the operating room for urgent debridement and evaluation. An operative Gram stain on a tissue sample shows large gram-positive rods.
Which one of the following organisms is likely to be isolated from the patient's tissue when cultured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae infection (which typically occurs from handling contaminated seafood, swine, or poultry) causes an erythematous papule on the fingers or hands that can spread but remains localized to the skin and lymph nodes.

B) CORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens causes gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis), a syndrome characterized by abrupt, severe pain and skin changes (discoloration, crepitus, and thin foul-smelling drainage) at the site of recent deep trauma. Gas gangrene results from extensive, rapid tissue necrosis and gas production. It should be treated urgently with surgical evaluation and intervention as well as antibiotics.

Key learning point: The presence of tissue myonecrosis and crepitus that develops within hours after a traumatic puncture of the skin is indicative of gas gangrene, also known as clostridial myonecrosis, which is caused by Clostridium perfringens.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, a subacute respiratory disease with tonsillar and pharyngeal pseudomembrane formation that can extend distally and compromise the airway. Cutaneous disease is rare and usually consists of chronic, shallow skin ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinomyces israelii can cause a deep-seated infection along the aerodigestive and reproductive tracts and can spread through fascial planes, but it is usually fairly indolent.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous exposure to Bacillus anthracis causes a papule that ulcerates and becomes covered by a black eschar with surrounding edema (anthrax).

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman who is currently receiving chemotherapy for stage III colon cancer is brought to the emergency department with a one-day history of severe right-thigh pain, fever, and generalized malaise.
Her temperature is 38.8°C, her blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. She is writhing with pain and appears acutely ill. Her right thigh looks slightly dusky, but there are no obvious skin findings, fluctuance, or swelling. Circulation to the lower leg seems intact on examination.
Initial laboratory studies reveal a leukocyte count of 30,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), a hemoglobin level of 10.0 g/dL (12.0–16.0), and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.0 mg/dL (0.6–1.1).
In addition to fluid resuscitation and empiric antibiotics, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's care?

choices.text: Blood cultures with further management guided by the results

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gas gangrene is a surgical emergency. Prompt surgical debridement, aggressive hemodynamic resuscitation, and initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics are crucial for definitive management. Close clinical monitoring would not be appropriate given the potential for rapid progression and the high mortality risk.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation, which includes hemodynamic instability and pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings, is consistent with a spontaneous necrotizing soft-tissue infection. Gas gangrene, in particular, should be suspected in light of the patient's colon cancer.

Clostridium perfringens is the pathogen most frequently involved in traumatic gas gangrene, whereas Clostridium septicum is more commonly implicated in spontaneous gas gangrene, particularly in patients with a history of gastrointestinal malignancy. These gas-producing bacteria secrete multiple exotoxins that trigger the release of inflammatory cytokines by the host’s immune system, causing local tissue necrosis, small-vessel thrombosis, and hemodynamic instability with septic shock and, often, multiorgan failure.

With gas gangrene, small-vessel thrombosis is often responsible for a pale or dusky appearance of the skin. Hemorrhagic bullae and crepitus tend to appear later in the course of the illness.

The most reliable way to make the diagnosis is by direct visualization of necrotic muscle and fascia, along with findings of gram-variable rods in the area of tissue damage. The 2014 Infectious Diseases Society of America guidelines for skin and soft-tissue infections recommend emergency surgical exploration of suspected gas gangrene followed by aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue.

Plain-film radiography, CT, and MRI of the affected area cannot rule out aggressive soft-tissue infections like this one. Although plain-film radiographs are often obtained in this setting, they lack sensitivity in detecting air in the soft tissues.

Key learning point: The optimal strategy to test for suspected gas gangrene is emergency surgical exploration.

C) INCORRECT:

Some patients with gas gangrene may have bacteremia. However, waiting for blood cultures to become positive is not appropriate given the potential for rapid progression and the high mortality risk. Moreover, the recovery of anaerobic bacteria (such as Clostridium species) in the laboratory is technically difficult, which often reduces the diagnostic yield of positive blood cultures in patients with confirmed gas gangrene.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI can reveal deep-tissue stranding and edema but may not detect the presence of necrotizing fasciitis or gas gangrene. More importantly, imaging studies like MRI can cause an unnecessary delay in definitive surgical exploration and debridement, which is crucial for the management of gas gangrene.

E) INCORRECT:

Although CT can reveal deep-tissue stranding and edema, it may not detect the presence of necrotizing fasciitis or gas gangrene. More importantly, imaging studies like CT can cause an unnecessary delay in definitive surgical exploration and debridement, which is crucial for the management of gas gangrene.

questions.text: A 52-year-old farmer with diabetes presents to the emergency department 24 hours after sustaining a deep laceration to the forearm from farm equipment. The patient reports severe muscle pain that has worsened significantly over the past 6 hours despite oral analgesics. Physical examination shows tense edema with bronze-colored skin changes and crackling on palpation. Vital signs are P, 118; T, 38.4°C (101.1°F). The patient appears confused. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Obtain MRI to assess extent of infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gas gangrene is a clinical diagnosis, and management should not be delayed for diagnostic studies. This patient's clinical presentation with crepitus, bronze skin discoloration, and systemic toxicity requires urgent multimodal management.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are inadequate for gas gangrene. The severe systemic toxicity and rapid progression of this infection demand aggressive multimodal treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

While tetanus prophylaxis is appropriate for deep farm equipment injuries, it is not the most appropriate immediate management step for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered as adjunctive treatment but should never delay surgical debridement.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Emergency surgical debridement is the most critical immediate intervention for gas gangrene. Severe muscle pain, crepitus, bronze skin discoloration, and systemic toxicity in a patient with a deep wound suggests clostridial myonecrosis. Prompt surgical exploration and debridement of all necrotic tissue is essential to prevent rapid progression to multiorgan failure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diabetes presents with a 6-hour history of progressive right thigh pain after a minor puncture wound from gardening yesterday. He appears ill with fever, tachycardia, and confusion. The thigh is swollen with red-purple discoloration and scattered hemorrhagic bullae. Crepitus is palpable over the affected area. His white blood cell count is 18,000/μL with 85% neutrophils, and lactate is 4.2 mmol/L. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and arrange urgent surgical consultation
Obtain MRI to determine the extent of soft tissue involvement
Perform bedside ultrasound to assess for fluid collections
Begin hyperbaric oxygen therapy while awaiting culture results
Administer IV antibiotics and reassess at 2 hour intervals for spread of infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with clinical features of gas gangrene, including rapid progression, crepitus, systemic toxicity, and skin changes. Gas gangrene requires immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical debridement of all necrotic tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI can show the characteristic feathering pattern of gas in soft tissues, but gas gangrene is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging should not delay treatment. This patient's clinical presentation with crepitus, systemic toxicity, and rapid progression requires immediate intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Bedside ultrasound may show gas in soft tissues but does not change immediate management. Gas gangrene is a clinical diagnosis that requires immediate antibiotic therapy and surgical intervention rather than additional diagnostic studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered as adjunctive treatment but is not the immediate priority. Surgery should not be delayed for this treatment, and immediate surgical debridement with antibiotics takes precedence over adjunctive therapies.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are inadequate for gas gangrene. This rapidly progressive necrotizing infection requires immediate surgical debridement. Serial assessments would allow further tissue destruction and systemic deterioration.
